thread.title_full: Juan Lagares is latest example of Terry Collins’ sudden genius | New York Post

author: Dan Martin
title: Juan Lagares is latest example of Terry Collins’ sudden genius
text:
Juan Lagares hadn’t scored a run since Sept. 13.
Since then, he’d had 27 plate appearances and gotten just four hits.
Still, Terry Collins went with the speedy center fielder to start Game 3 of the NLDS against the Dodgers instead of Michael Cuddyer or Michael Conforto.
And like so much has lately for the Mets, Lagares made Collins look smart, scoring three times in Monday’s 13-7 win over the Dodgers to take a 2-1 series lead.
It’s not like Collins had any ideal choices when it came to his third outfielder.
There was Lagares, who struggled at the plate all season.
Or he could go with Cuddyer, who had terrible numbers against Dodgers lefty Brett Anderson, and was brutal in left field in Game 1 in Los Angeles.
Collins could have also turned to Conforto, but the lefty-swinging rookie’s most significant flaw is an inability to hit southpaws.
So Collins went with Lagares in center — surrounded by Yoenis Cespedes and Curtis Granderson — and Lagares doubled, walked and made a nice running catch of Andre Ethier’s fly to right-center in the eighth.
He scored in the four-run second and then was the first batter to face Dodgers reliever Alex Wood to start the fourth and promptly doubled to right-center, scoring on Daniel Murphy’s single.
“You never know what’s gonna happen in this game,” Lagares said. “I haven’t been playing much and maybe I haven’t been playing so good, but I kept the same approach and stayed ready for any opportunity.”
Collins said there were a number of factors that weighed into his decision.
“Number 1, Michael [Cuddyer] is 1-for-12 against Anderson, so we didn’t think that was a good matchup,” Collins said before the game.
And that also left Conforto out of the lineup.
“The one thing we haven’t asked Michael Conforto to do since he’s been called up to the big leagues is start a game against a left-handed pitcher and I didn’t think Game 3 in the playoffs, with all the other attention going on to what’s going to happen out there tonight, that it was the best chance to give him his first shot,” Collins said.
Cuddyer and Conforto both entered the game as pinch hitters, with Cuddyer walking in the fifth and Conforto driving in a run with a sacrifice fly in the seventh.
Lagares, who appeared in Game 1 as a defensive replacement in center and went 0-for-1 with a ninth-inning groundout, said he feels like he’s never left.
“I’m just waiting for any opportunity,” Lagares said. “If I play hard, good things will happen.”
